description: From Medieval Latin contemporārius, from Latin con- (“with, together”) + temporārius (“of time”), from tempus (“time”).

adjectives.description: contemporary (comparative more contemporary, superlative most contemporary)

entries.meaning: From the same time period, coexistent in time; contemporaneous.
Modern, of the present age (shorthand for ‘contemporary with the present’).
Someone or something living at the same time, or of roughly the same age as another.
examples: Cervantes was a contemporary of Shakespeare.
The early mammals inherited the earth by surviving their saurian contemporaries.

definitionGroups.group: Something existing at the same time.

examples: Annexation therefore was inevitable; but (as I have said above) it was not necessarily of prime importance in our national policy, and there has been no need to exaggerate—as I fear many of our contemporaries have exaggerated—  […]
